newsitem.title: USA: Pa. House considers $17 bln 1998 budget -- paper.
newsitem.headline: Pa. House considers $17 bln 1998 budget -- paper.

text.p: The Pennsylvania House has begun debate on a proposed $17 billion fiscal 1998 budget, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported Wednesday.
The Senate is expected to consider the budget over the next two weeks, with May as a target date for the governor's signature. The fiscal year begins July 1.
On Monday, Pennsylvania said its fiscal 1997 surplus had grown to $370 million, sparking debate on whether it should be spent or saved.

The current budget plan would increase spending on education by more than $150 million. The poorest 135 school districts would receive increases of at least four percent over 1997 levels, and the rest would see one percent boosts, the paper said.
The budget also would trim business taxes by $41.5 million.

Debate has not yet begun on Gov. Tom Ridge's separate proposal to raise $400 million a year for road construction and maintenance through a gas tax and fee increase. Ridge's plan to sell state-owned liquor stores will also be considered separately from the budget.
